page.title: 07FARLEY'S HISTORIC BUILDINGS
page.content: Farley is on the edge of Clarendon Forest,an ancient wood that used to cover most of the area. Farley means {"far meadow".}There are some older houses, but the most notable buildings are the Church, Wardenry and Almshouses. These were paid for by Sir Stephen Fox, an advisor to king Charles II and later a member of Parliament for Salisbury. He was born in Farley and bought the estate here. The Wardenry, originally the vicarage, was built in 1681. The architect was Alexander Fort, an associate of Sir Christopher Wren. The buildings are of red brick. The church has five stained glass windows. The Wardenry, although a simple outward design, has attractive oak panelling and elaborate plaster ceilings inside.
